fields.description:
As a cloud administrator I want to be able to register my cloud (region) with the federation so I can use the global identity services (IAM/STS)

What am I going to do as a user: CLI for registration of a cloud with another cloud.
When they submit the request these things will happen. (more details...)

Acceptance:
Given when then
Must support at least 20 regions
Geographic location should not prevent but time limits are not expected. 
It should function like our service registration "local" then used to verify scenario.
at end of sprint this will be tested... scrum goal

Given an authenticated cloud administrator with access to both regions 
When the administrator registers as being part of the same federation 
Then depending on the design there is some specific way for the administator to determine they have successfully established the federation relaitonship.

comments.body:
Hi [~sjones],

This looks great however I had trouble establishing federation if I did not specify the region name as {{region-1}} OR {{region-*}} for example. Can we use more useful region names like {{euca-us-east}} , {{euca-us-west}} etc. ?

Cheers,
Deependra

[~sjones],

Should {{eucalyptus.<system.dns.dnsdomain>}} resolve for a given cloud?  Does the region registration support DNS names for components?

I ask because I tried to resolve {{eucalyptus.a-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com}} and I saw the following:
{code}
# nslookup eucalyptus.a-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
;; Got SERVFAIL reply from 10.1.1.254, trying next server
Server:		10.1.1.254
Address:	10.1.1.254#53

** server can't find eucalyptus.a-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com: NXDOMAIN
{code}
However DNS is configured correctly:
{code}
# nslookup compute.a-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
Server:		10.1.1.254
Address:	10.1.1.254#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:	compute.a-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com
Address: 10.111.5.59
{code}

[~hspencer], there are currently no DNS changes related to region federation. The old DNS names (walrus, eucalyptus) are currently not present in 4.2 and will most likely be dropped (I've opened EUCA-10919 for tracking that change)

[~hspencer], you probably need to set "region.region_ssl_verify_hostnames" to false, unless you have configured SSL with a valid certificate for the host. This is not a configuration that should generally be used, but is OK for testing.

[~hspencer], setting "region.region_enable_ssl" disables use of HTTPS, so the "region.region_ssl*" settings are then not used. If you want to see the other regions with the output of euca-describe-regions then you need to configure that as described in EUCA-10450, i.e. you'd need to add the endpoints for the compute service to the "Services" section of each region.

Thanks [~sjones],

The output from 'euca-describe-regions' shows correctly now:
{code}
# euca-describe-regions
REGION	region-1	http://compute.g-05-01.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
REGION	region-2	http://compute.a-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
{code}

From my understanding, the --region option for any euca2ools command will be a bit overloaded right?  --region is used with euca2ools configuration, so how does it determine which region to use if just the region name is passed?  I raise this question because I see the following when I test it out with {{euca-describe-availability-zones}}:
{code}
[root@g-22-07 ~]# euca-describe-regions
REGION	region-1	http://compute.g-05-01.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/
REGION	region-2	http://compute.a-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/

# euca-describe-availability-zones --region region-2 verbose
AVAILABILITYZONE	one	10.111.1.173 arn:euca:eucalyptus:one:cluster:one-cc-1/
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- vm types	free / max   cpu   ram  disk
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.small	0011 / 0011   1    256     5
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- t1.micro	0011 / 0011   1    256     5
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.medium	0005 / 0005   1    512    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.medium	0005 / 0005   2    512    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.large	0005 / 0005   2    512    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.xlarge	0005 / 0005   2   1024    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.xlarge	0003 / 0003   2   2048    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.xlarge	0003 / 0003   2   2048    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m3.xlarge	0003 / 0003   4   2048    15
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.2xlarge	0001 / 0001   2   4096    30
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m3.2xlarge	0001 / 0001   4   4096    30
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cc1.4xlarge	0000 / 0000   8   3072    60
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.4xlarge	0000 / 0000   8   4096    60
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- hi1.4xlarge	0000 / 0000   8   6144   120
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cc2.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  16   6144   120
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cg1.4xlarge	0000 / 0000  16   12288   200
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cr1.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  16   16384   240
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- hs1.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  48   119808  24000

# euca-describe-availability-zones --region region-1 verbose
AVAILABILITYZONE	one	10.111.1.173 arn:euca:eucalyptus:one:cluster:one-cc-1/
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- vm types	free / max   cpu   ram  disk
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.small	0011 / 0011   1    256     5
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- t1.micro	0011 / 0011   1    256     5
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.medium	0005 / 0005   1    512    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.medium	0005 / 0005   2    512    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.large	0005 / 0005   2    512    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.xlarge	0005 / 0005   2   1024    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.xlarge	0003 / 0003   2   2048    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.xlarge	0003 / 0003   2   2048    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m3.xlarge	0003 / 0003   4   2048    15
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.2xlarge	0001 / 0001   2   4096    30
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m3.2xlarge	0001 / 0001   4   4096    30
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cc1.4xlarge	0000 / 0000   8   3072    60
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.4xlarge	0000 / 0000   8   4096    60
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- hi1.4xlarge	0000 / 0000   8   6144   120
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cc2.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  16   6144   120
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cg1.4xlarge	0000 / 0000  16   12288   200
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cr1.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  16   16384   240
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- hs1.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  48   119808  24000
{code}

Both availability zones are using '10.111.1.173' as the zone location.  Based upon the region config I used below to enable the display of regions via DescribeRegions, '10.111.1.173' is associated to 'region-1', not 'region-2'.  Is there a different way I should be using the parameter here?

{code}
{
    "Regions": [
        {
            "Name": "region-1",
            "CertificateFingerprintDigest": "SHA-256",
            "CertificateFingerprint": "7C:60:18:7E:92:FF:3E:C9:32:4F:28:13:C7:91:54:E6:17:7A:E1:AD:01:B3:3F:C7:71:FE:88:FF:34:1A:6F:6D",
            "IdentifierPartitions": [
                1
            ],
            "Services": [
                {
                    "Type": "identity",
                    "Endpoints": [
                        "http://10.111.1.173:8773/services/Identity"
                    ]
                },
                {
                    "Type": "compute",
                    "Endpoints": [
                        "http://compute.g-05-01.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/"
                    ]
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "Name": "region-2",
            "CertificateFingerprintDigest": "SHA-256",
            "CertificateFingerprint": "B3:70:8B:35:BE:B2:06:69:E9:6A:4C:53:0D:34:30:A4:82:2A:A5:69:96:80:6F:FC:E8:0C:7A:74:8D:F6:DD:3A",
            "IdentifierPartitions": [
                2
            ],
            "Services": [
                {
                    "Type": "identity",
                    "Endpoints": [
                        "http://10.111.5.59:8773/services/Identity"
                    ]
                },
                {
                    "Type": "compute",
                    "Endpoints": [
                        "http://compute.a-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com:8773/"
                    ]
                }
            ]
        }
    ]
}
{code}

CC'ing [~gholms] for his insight here as well.

Here is the error I got here when tried to access the EC2 resources on the region-2 cloud with the region-1 credentials: {code} [root@g-22-07 ~]# euca-describe-availability-zones -U [~sjones],

Opened EUCA-10925 reflecting the NPE error. Let me know if you need any additional information.
